contrasts.commentary: Negative language leans on negators and sanction terms (“not”, “no”, “ban”, “police”), casting actions as failures; positive language uses evaluatives (“great”, “good”, “well”, “thank”) that attribute credit and efficacy.
Where critics emphasize bans and policing around football and demonstrations, supporters speak in terms of protection, rights, and safety—same domain, different framing.
Both sides invoke the nation (“UK”), but negatives pair it with scarcity or decline (“need”, “no”), while positives pair it with agency and progress (“make”, “right”).

recommendations.message: Lead with concrete actions on safety and even‑handed enforcement; show how decisions were applied consistently.
Acknowledge harm from antisemitism and all hate crimes; outline channels for reporting and follow‑up.
Publish measurable targets on housing/safety; update progress at set intervals to demonstrate delivery.
